doc.title: GS TWIG Notes: Special 'Back to School' W(S)IG: This Summer in Global Research - August 29, 2025
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/GS TWIG Notes Special Back to School TWSIG This Summer in Global Research August 29 2025GS TWIG Notes Special Back to Sc_2025-08-29

passages.text: TWIG NOTES This Week (Summer) in Global Research

Jan Hatzius sees a path for the Fed to restart its rate cutting cycle at its September meeting as the labor market has already eroded more than originally thought, and US output has slowed, creating a situation where US growth has hit a pace below which the labor market weakens in a self- reinforcing fashion in the Aug- 4 Global Views, "On Course for Cuts." Our call remains for three consecutive 25bp cuts in September, October, and December, followed by two more 25bp cuts in 1H26. See also Hatzius and David Mericle's postview of Fed Chair Powell's Jackson Hole speech, "USA: Powell Says Baseline Outlook and Shifting Risks 'May Warrant Adjusting Our Policy Stance,' FOMC Returns to Flexible Inflation Targeting, Removes 'Shortfalls' Language From Monetary Policy Framework," Mericle's Aug- 17 note, "Slower Job Growth Makes the Case for a Cut," and Joseph Briggs' Aug- 19 "US Consumer Dashboard: August 2025."

In Europe, Jari Stehn and Giovanni Pierdomenico believe Europe has an opportunity to materially boost its growth prospects over the next 2- 3 years amid improving sentiment and heightened US macro policy uncertainty in the Aug- 14 note, "Europe's Moment." While the continent still faces significant structural headwinds, we think there are opportunities to drive growth through increased public investment, leadership in growth industries, financial market reforms, and further integration of the internal market. And in the UK, the BoE took a hawkish tilt at its early- August meeting even as it delivered an as- expected 25bp rate cut writes James Moberly in an Aug- 7 note "BoE Recap—Hawkish Cut But Still on Course for November." See also Niklas Garnadt's Jul- 16 update, "Germany—Structural Manufacturing Headwinds Persist, But Cyclical Outlook Brightens."
In Asia, Andrew Tilton highlights how policy choices in the US (import tariffs) and China (low- cost manufacturing juggernaut) are upending Asia's longstanding,

goods- export driven, growth model in an Aug- 15 update, "Revisiting the Regional Growth Model." In the near- term, look countries across Asia (ex- Japan) to further ease macro policy. Longer term, we think the path forward includes a combination of export specialization and increased reliance on domestic demand. And in China, Hui Shan writes that policy maker's shrink- to- grow initiative (anti- involution) is unlikely to significantly impact growth, and structural issues impacting the economy (a property market slump, deflation, and labor market weakness) are unlikely to be fixed quickly in the Aug- 20 note, "China Matters: Not in a Hurry." Finally in Japan, Tomohiro Ota raised our GDP growth forecast on the back of US- Japan tariff negotiations in a Jul- 24 note, "Japan: Raising our GDP Forecasts Slightly Following Japan- US Trade Deal." See also the Aug- 20 "EM Macro Navigator: After the Tariffs."

The path for US equities has become complicated, especially now that the market has taken credit for both more growth and more policy easing write Dominic Wilson and Kamakshya Trivedi in and Aug- 18 Global Market Views note, "Easing in Season." Seek out positions that provide leverage to the Fed easing that we expect, but that still protect from deeper economic recession worries if they materialize. Lean into: dollar weakening and bonds rallying. Christian Mueller- Glissmann also highlights elevated risk of a market correction amid elevated equity valuations, low volatility, a weakening business cycle, and the potential for negative growth or rate shocks in the Aug- 14 note, "Goldilocks vs. the Bears." Turning to Asia, John Kwon, Tim Moe and team introduce a new tool for measuring market risk which points to only moderate risk of drawdown in "Asia: Are markets too complacent? Introducing RADA: Regional Asia Drawdown Risk model." Buy the dip, if we get one.

Finally, in the US, David Kostin illustrates how strong 2Q earnings season was (especially relative to low expectations), and how earnings revisions are accelerating on the back of results in an Aug- 15 Kickstart, "2Q 2025 earnings season recap." If earnings can keep moving higher and the rates can move lower, stocks should be well- supported.

A Retail summer. A spike in trading activity in unprofitable stocks, penny stocks, and stocks with elevated EV/sales multiples pushed our Speculative Trading Indicator (STI) to its highest level outside of 1998- 2001 and 2020- 2021 (both periods that were soon followed by Tech stock crashes) writes Ben Snider in the Jul- 24 "US Macroscope." And we see further signs of speculation in options markets, IPOs, SPAC issuance, retail trading, and the recent rally in heavily shorted stocks. The good news: historically, such a rise in speculative activity has actually been a signal of strong near- term returns (3-, 6-, and 12- month). See also last week's "Hedge Fund Trend Monitor" and "Mutual Fundamentals." In Europe, however, while stocks with high short interest have rallied, Sharon Bell points out that the retail trading phenomenon we see in the US has no parallel in Europe's institutional- dominated stock markets where market concentration is low, IPO's have yet to pick up, and Value, not Growth, is outperforming in "Europe has few parallels to US speculative
trading activity boom" (Jul- 29).

Blame the messenger. Joseph Briggs writes that if data quality worsens in the wake of policy, data collectors and social shifts, growth could be negatively impacted if a central bank needs to reverse a rate hike or rate cut, and cross- country currency correlations could create inefficiencies as well in the Aug- 10 global note, "Data Concerns, Central Bank Reactions, and Economic Costs." Separately, and focused on the US, Ronnie Walker writes that the indicators that have had larger declines in quality in recent years have had larger surprises to consensus forecasts in the Aug- 11 note, "What Not to Watch: Data Reliability and Market Sensitivity to Economic Surprises."

Stablecoin. Our analysts wrote this summer about the emergence of digital currencies and payment systems in a series of notes: Allison Nathan's Top of Mind, "Stablecoin summer" (Aug- 19), Filippo Taddei's "The Digital Euro and the European Financial System" (Aug- 14), Bill Zu and Will Marshall's Rates note, "The Financial System Implications of Payment Stablecoins" (Jul- 25), Makoto Kuroda's Banks note, "Japan Banks: Nikkei reports Japan's first yen- based stablecoin could launch this fall" (Aug- 18) and Sinyoung Park's "Korea Fintech: What are the potential KRW- stablecoin revenue streams?" (Jul- 14). US sector analysts Will Nance and James Yaro also wrote that stablecoin and asset tokenization is unlikely to disrupt legacy payment platforms as much as markets may currently expect in "Fintech: Assessing the opportunities for Stablecoin adoption" (Aug- 19) and "Reflecting on recent investor and company conversations on stablecoins as debate shifts towards use cases" (Jun- 30). Cross- border transactions, however, can very much benefit from blockchain technology, and the holy grail is the tokenization of assets (i.e., stocks, bonds, real estate, etc.).

Gold. Lina Thomas and Daan Struyven provide a deep dive into the gold market in the Aug- 17 note, "Gold Market Primer." Supply/demand models for forecasting gold prices do not work because gold lasts forever, the price is inelastic to new supply, and gold is not consumed, but rather stored. As a result, gold markets clear through changes in ownership. Focus on: conviction buyers (ETFs, central banks, and speculators); and opportunistic buyers (EM households).

Prime time in China. China's senior policymakers are recognizing the importance of private- owned enterprises (vs. state- owned ones), and are easing regulation, paving the way for a catch- up trade in China's stock market writes Singer Lau at the very start of the summer in a trio of notes from Jun- 15: "China Strategy: The comeback of Chinese POEs (Part 1): The tide has turned," "Part 2: Why large POEs are getting larger," and "Part 3: The ascent of Prominent 10." And as we exit the summer, Singer believes the rally we have seen has legs to move higher in the Aug- 28 China note, "Why the liquidity- driven rally has further to go."
Jim Covello and Eric Sheridan explore the opportunity for new AI applications to disrupt legacy profit pools, amidst ongoing concerns that vast AI infrastructure

investment has yet to yield any tangible returns in an early- summer note, "Analyzing the Impact of Al on Industry Profit." (Jun- 24). And over the course of the summer, concerns about how sustainable the infrastructure investment phase was faded as hyperscalers and NVDA delivered solid quarterly results and outlooks (see Eric Sheridan's Aug- 20 note, "Internet: Recapping Takeaways & Debates; Focus Stocks Going Forward," Kash Rangan's Jul- 31 note, "MSFT: The Al Halo Effect Ripples up the Stack," and Jim Schneider's Aug- 28 note "NVDA: see meaningful upside heading into 2026").

And as we leg out of summer and not fall, Gabriela Borges and Kash Rangan make the case for both legacy software providers and a new cohort of Al- native companies to emerge in this next Tech era, as they push back against the software stock bears in "GenAl Part XII: Updated thoughts on the 'Death of Software' bear case" (Aug- 17). They also expect faster adoption of Al agents relative to SaaS, at the enterprise level, with the agents achieving \(+60\%\) of the Software TAM as they discussed in a note way back on Jun- 16, "Agentic Al expands the App Software TAM." And Schneider cautions that a lack of near- term catalysts could temporarily stall out the rally in Semis stocks in "Semiconductors: Trading the 'Al Autumn'."

Autonomous cars and robots. In China, Allen Chang outlined the \(\) 61bn\(robotaxi opportunity that is developing in a Jul - 16 update, "Raising Robotaxi TAM and Fleet size in China on operators' rising deployment." And Mark Delaney, Eric Sheridan, and team highlighted the much smaller developing opportunity in the US in a Jun - 9 note, "AVs move from concept to commercialization (Jun - 9)." Separately, Jacqueline Du wrote that she is seeing decelerating demand for factory robots amidst trade war uncertainty, but ongoing investment in humanoid machines in the Jun - 6 note, "Automation: Slightly softened FA while somewhat improved PA."

Electrification. Alberto Gandolfi reiterates our view that European datacenter growth should drive a power demand surge, boosting electrification companies' growth prospects in the Jul- 30 update, "Deal activity suggests we could be at an inflection point." See also Brian Singer and team's Aug- 17 note, "Green Capex: The power of Power outlook intact following latest US renewables guidance," Michele Della Vigna's Jul- 24 note, "Carbonomics: hydrocarbon and renewables race in US energy," and Brian Lee and Carly Davenport's Jun- 25 US Nuclear power update, "Nuclear power uprates a potential driver of near- to medium- term upside."

Datacenters. Jim Schneider, Allen Chang, and team push out our forecast for peak global datacenter capacity utilization to the end of this year as demand remains robust and new datacenter construction struggles to keep up in "Global Datacenters: Supply/demand update (Jul- 16)." And in China, Tim Zhao looks for a potential datacenter demand inflection with NVDA's Blackwell Chips being allowed into China, in "Eyes on NVDA Blackwell China variant approval" (Aug- 29). See also Allen Chang's Aug- 28 Global Semis note, "CHIPS Act 3: China capex continues to grow; migration ongoing despite challenges."

Europe Telcos. Andrew Lee sees an opportunity to more aggressively lean into potential Telco targets across Europe in the Jul- 31 deep dive, "Mobile consolidation: Analyzing the upside from the next phase of Digital Infrastructure deregulation."

Our analysts surveyed how China's 'Anti- Involution' campaign - measures and regulations to cut production capacity and curb disorderly pricing schemes - could impact a range of sectors. Jacqueline Du writes that anti- involution could drive a prolonged, but modest, decline in automation demand in China's factory automation market in "Defensive+AI as barbell approach to counter softening FA" (Aug- 6). And Nikhil Bhandari writes that while a few provinces have issued notices to asses old facilities in China's refining and petrochemical industry, the initiative should be positive for ex- China refiners as it should result in less Chinese oil in the global market in "Assessing potential impact from China's Anti- Involution" (Jul- 23). Separately, Mengwen Wang expects higher Polysilicon prices and an earlier profitability inflection if the measures are well implemented in "China Solar: Key Q&As on Anti- Involution" (Jul- 22). And Matt Greene and Paul Young discuss how inventory fluctuations are impacting Australia's steel market in "Feedback on Iron Ore & Steel Market Developments" (Jul- 23).

Separately, in China, Tianyi Yan highlights the emerging opportunity to service the wealthy over- 50 population with healthcare offerings that require out- of- pocket payments and treatments that are not covered by Chinese national health insurance in "Rise of the Silver Yuan" (Jul- 28).

Semis. Jim Schneider paves a path to almost \(\) 1\$ trillion in cost savings through AI implementations by 2030, justifying AI infrastructure spending as he launches comprehensive coverage of the US Semis sector in three Jul- 10 notes: "Initiate on Digital Semiconductors and EDA Software," "Initiate on US Semi Cap Equipment, Storage, and Foundry," and "Initiate on Analog and RF Semiconductors." Separately, in mainland China, look for WFE expansion, the ramp up of local semiconductor production equipment (SPE), and increasing demand for diversified semi supply chains to benefit Chinese SPE component makers writes Allen Chan in "Initiating SPE components" (Aug- 14). And in Taiwan, Verena Jeng believes growing demand for AI server and switch customization and high- speed connectivity will help drive the next wave of AI infrastructure investment in "Initiating AI/Switch" (Aug- 14). Finally, look for AI to drive increasing adoption of semiconductor advanced packaging writes Evelyn Yu in "Advanced packaging to embark on its next frontier" (Jun- 25).
Autos. Do Hyoung Kim initiated on Korean autos with a preference for companies with rising market share and undemanding valuations, in "Climbing the wall of worry; Buy Hyundai Motor & Kia" (Aug- 27).

Casinos. Lizzie Dove leans into US Casinos with high quality assets and a clear catalyst path, as well as those with, strong FCF generation without a daunting capex cycle in "Focus on cash, capex cycles and catalyst paths" (Jul- 7).

Other Tech. Corinne Johnson leans into US Biotech stocks with a clear clinical, regulatory, or commercial catalyst past and where we think the outcome will be positive in "Resuming coverage of Emerging Biotechnology with a focus on key debates" (Jul- 10). And Matt Dellatorre initiated on the US Generics Pharma sector with a focus on EBITDA growth and pipeline optionality for companies that develop patented drugs of their own as well as manufacture generics in "Generics: Growth opportunities in a defensive industry" (Jun- 6). Separately, Anthony Valentini launched coverage of the US Defense Tech sector, assuming some stock coverage from Noah Poonak, with a constructive view as the DoD is increasingly focused on reducing costs and finding better ways to more efficiently defend US interests in "Launching Defense Tech as industry transformation is under way" (Jun- 29).

Consumer. In Brazil, Felipe Rached initiated and assumed coverage of a slew of retailers with a focus on idiosyncratic stories that have undemanding valuations, in "Brazil Retail: Launch coverage" (Jul- 28). Separately, Brooke Roach initiated coverage on three US footwear stocks in "Competitive market dynamics offsetting idiosyncratic momentum" (Jul- 1). And Leah Jordan leaned into stocks with favorable exposure to a growing high- protein diet trend in the US in "Food: Strong protein demand, with diverging supply outlooks" (Jun- 23).

Gold & Shipping. Sustained high gold prices coupled with increased production should drive superior cash flow across the Australia's Gold Mining sector, fortifying balance sheets, and strengthening returns writes Hugo Nicolaci in "Initiate on six Growth & Leveraged Gold mid- caps" (Jul- 2). Separately, Norihiro Miyazaki expects a fairly balanced supply/demand environment for container ships in 2026 once the decline in charter- out rates incentivizes the long awaited scrapping of old, inefficient vessels from the market in "Japan Shipping: initiating 3 stocks" (Jun- 24).

Tech. Speakers at our European AI & Semis Symposium (held Jul 30- 31) highlighted how significant productivity gains and cost reductions are driving increasingly widespread Gen AI adoption, writes Alex Duval in "Key Takeaways" (Aug- 14). Separately, George Tong and Gabriela Borges met with a host of private companies and academics throughout Silicon Valley in late August and capture the highlights in "Takeaways From Our 2nd Annual Silicon Valley AI Field Trip" (Aug- 21). Finally, Jacqueline Du came away from the 2025 World Robot Conference (held Aug- 9) impressed by the improvement in overall product performance and strong consumer traffic in "2025 WRC takeaways" (Aug- 11).

Biotech. Companies on our Boston Biotech Bus Tour focused on advancing late- stage pipeline assets toward regulatory approval and successful commercial launch, while emphasizing differentiated safety/efficacy profiles and addressing competitive positioning in their respective therapeutic areas write Salveen Richter, Corinne Johnson, Andrea Newkirk, Paul Choi, and Rich Law in "Day 1 takeaways" (Aug- 5), "Day 2 takeaways" (Aug- 6), and "Day 3 takeaways" (Aug- 7).
Consumer & Industrial. Companies at our London Business Services, Leisure &

Transport conference (held Jun 23- 24) provided a muted outlook for travel and hotel bookings, while airlines were mixed about demand visibility, but shipping seems resilient, write Patrick Creuset and Ben Andrews in "Day 1" (Jun- 23), "Day 2" (Jun- 24) and "Feedback from 21st Business Services, Leisure & Transport Conference" (Jun- 24).

We, Chris Husey and Sarah Herr, hereby certify that all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect our personal views about the subject company or companies and its or their securities. We also certify that no part of our compensation was, is or will be, directly or indirectly, related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this report.
Unless otherwise stated, the individuals listed on the cover page of this report are analysts in Goldman Sachs' Global Investment Research division.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
Not Rated (NR). The investment rating, target price and earnings estimates (where relevant) are removed pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when

Goldman Sachs is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or in a strategic transaction involving this company, when there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints due to Goldman Sachs' involvement in a transaction, and in certain other circumstances. Early- Stage Biotech (ES). An investment rating and a target price are not assigned pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when this company neither has a drug, treatment or medical device that has passed a Phase II clinical trial nor a license to distribute a post- Phase II drug, treatment or medical device. Rating Suspended (RS). Goldman Sachs Research has suspended the investment rating and price target for this stock, because there is not a sufficient fundamental basis for determining an investment rating or target price. The previous investment rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this stock and should not be relied upon. Coverage Suspended (CS). Goldman Sachs has suspended coverage of this company. Not Covered (NC). Goldman Sachs does not cover this company.

GSBE - Succursal en España (Madrid branch) subject (to a limited extent) to local supervision by the Bank of Spain disseminates research in the Kingdom of Spain; GSBE - Succursale Italia (Milan branch) to the relevant applicable extent, subject to local supervision by the Bank of Italy (Banca d'Italia) and the Italian Companies and Exchange Commission (Commissione Nazionale per le Società e la Borsa "Consob") disseminates research in Italy; This research is for our clients only. Other than disclosures relating to Goldman Sachs, this research is based on current public information that we consider reliable, but we do not represent it as accurate or complete, and it should not be relied on as such. The information, opinions, estimates and forecasts contained herein are as of the date hereof and are subject to change without prior notification. We seek to update our research as appropriate, but various regulations may prevent us from doing so. Other than certain industry reports published on a periodic basis, the large majority of reports are published at irregular intervals as appropriate in the analyst's judgment.

Goldman Sachs conducts a global full- service, integrated investment banking, investment management, and brokerage business. We have investment banking and other business relationships with a substantial percentage of the companies covered by Global Investment Research. Goldman Sachs & Co. LLC, the United States broker dealer, is a member of SIPC (https://www.sipc.org).

Our salespeople, traders, and other professionals may provide oral or written market commentary or trading strategies to our clients and principal trading desks that reflect opinions that are contrary to the opinions expressed in this research. Our asset management area, principal trading desks and investing businesses may make investment decisions that are inconsistent with the recommendations or views expressed in this research.

The analysts named in this report may have from time to time discussed with our clients, including Goldman Sachs salespersons and traders, or may discuss in this report, trading strategies that reference catalysts or events that may have a near- term impact on the market price of the equity securities discussed in this report, which impact may be directionally counter to the analyst's published price target expectations for such stocks. Any such trading strategies are distinct from and do not affect the analyst's fundamental equity rating for such stocks, which rating reflects a stock's return potential relative to its coverage universe as described herein.

We and our affiliates, officers, directors, and employees will from time to time have long or short positions in, act as principal in, and buy or sell, the securities or derivatives, if any, referred to in this research, unless otherwise prohibited by regulation or Goldman Sachs policy.

The views attributed to third party presenters at Goldman Sachs arranged conferences, including individuals from other parts of Goldman Sachs, do not necessarily reflect those of Global Investment Research and are not an official view of Goldman Sachs.

Any third party referenced herein, including any salespeople, traders and other professionals or members of their household, may have positions in the products mentioned that are inconsistent with the views expressed by analysts named in this report.

This research is not an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy any security in any jurisdiction where such an offer or solicitation would be illegal. It does not constitute a personal recommendation or take into account the particular investment objectives, financial situations, or needs of individual clients. Clients should consider whether any advice or recommendation in this research is suitable for their particular circumstances and, if appropriate, seek professional advice, including tax advice. The price and value of investments referred to in this research and the income from them may fluctuate. Past performance is not a guide to future performance, future returns are not guaranteed, and a loss of original capital may occur. Fluctuations in exchange rates could have adverse effects on the value or price of, or income derived from, certain investments.
Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors.

Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/character-risks.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fom disclosures. Transaction costs may be significant in option strategies calling for multiple purchase and sales of options such as spreads. Supporting documentation will be supplied upon request.

Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
Disclosure information is also available at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html or from Research Compliance, 200 West Street, New York, NY 10282.
